div.head: Open Session
div.p: Committee Chairman Warren Kimball called the meeting to order at 9 a.m.

William Z. Slany reminded everyone that this was a public session and that classified material should not be discussed during this part of the meeting. Kimball stated that we need to bear in mind the difference between closed and classified. He requested that anyone who wants to discuss classified material during the closed part of the meeting should so state.

div.head: Adoption of the Minutes of the February, May, and August Meetings
div.p: Kimball asked if anyone had any comments on the minutes of the February and August meetings (he withdrew discussion of the May minutes until the closed portion of the meeting). Jane Picker suggested that on p. 34 of the February minutes, in the first complete paragraph, the second sentence should read: “State raised as a problem the possible future cooperation of other agencies.” Anna Nelson suggested that in line 3 of the first full paragraph on p. 19, the reference should be to “an ISOO (1991) report” and that in the first line of the first full paragraph on p. 48, “could” should be changed to “would.” The changes were approved, and Kimball stated that the February minutes were adopted.

Concerning the August minutes, Arnold Taylor requested an addition to a paragraph on p. 6: “Taylor raised the issue of USIA material at the University of Arkansas, and Langbart said they could discuss that at a later time.” The change was approved, and Kimball stated that the August minutes were adopted.

Kimball said that all three sets of minutes would be available in the State Department Reading Room on Friday. He noted unfamiliar faces and asked those present to identify themselves. They were Tim Weiner of The New York Times and two (a third entered the meeting later) reporters from Japanese newspapers, Asahi Shimbun and Yomiuri Shimbun.

div.head: Amendment of the Foreign Relations Law
div.p: Kimball turned to the question of possible amendments to the 1991 Foreign Relations law. He had spoken to committee staffers on the Hill, who supported the idea. First, he noted that there is no other committee with a legislative mandate dealing with foreign policy records, and he thought it was appropriate at this time to expand that mandate. Second, he pointed out that the 26-year rule for access to records was a problem with CIA. HO historians sometimes need to look at records less than 26 years old. Now is the time to raise the issue.

Slany agreed, stating that since HO is compiling by administration, we need access to be well within the 26-year line. Kimball thought the problem might arise from confusion of declassification with compilation, but Page Miller stated that the CIA had refused during the drafting of the statute to accept less than a 26-year rule because of other legislative requirements.

David Herschler commented that the reference in the law to “originating agency” concerning declassification requirements should be changed to “originating/reviewing agencies.” In some cases, a reviewing agency that was not the originating agency but had equity in the document has argued that the time limit in the law did not apply to them.

Kimball noted that Congressional staffers he had talked to would like to have the Committee’s suggestions in January when Congress convenes. He asked Committee members to think about this and give him their suggestions. Jane Picker could put them into legalese.
Kimball also emphasized that he thought the Committee should make a strong statement supporting a new Executive Order.

div.head: Report by William Z. Slany, The Historian
div.p: Kimball asked Slany for the Historian’s report. Slany, who had circulated to the Committee a written report with 20 attachments in advance of the meeting, stated that HO is eliminating the backlog of compiled volumes awaiting declassification and publication. In the next year we will publish 20 volumes, and by the end of next year, we will have published 50 volumes since the passage of the legislation. Now we need to concentrate our efforts on completing the compilation off the volumes on the Johnson administration. We are working on expanding the scope of the series while reducing the volume of material published.

Half dozen senior Foreign Service officers (FSOs) have been assigned to HO. They are reviewing manuscript and performing other duties associated with the Foreign Relations series. Two of them are scheduled to review the material at the Central Intelligence Agency on Guatemala and Iran and make suggestions. We know there is a lot on Guatemala, but only a little on Iran. He noted that the FSOs will not compile the volumes; other members of the HO staff, who normally work on technical editing and declassification, have been drafted to help with compiling.

Melvyn Leffler questioned using FSOs to work on Foreign Relations. Slany pointed out that HO is not authorized to spend money to bring in outside reviewers and these officers give us extra sets of eyes to review manuscript. One FSO has looked at the Kennedy/Khrushchev correspondence and suggested asking the Russian Foreign Ministry if our collection of correspondence was complete. We are not obligated to take their advice.

Kimball stated that his impression was that FSOs vary greatly in their views on declassification; it is hard to generalize. Anna Nelson was concerned that an FSO might say a document didn’t belong in a compilation because he didn’t like it. Slany replied that they have no veto power. Picker asked if the FSOs were assigned on the basis of their past experience. She also expressed concern about their objectivity.

Slany stated that the officers are assigned on the basis of expertise. He commented that they tend to want more, rather than fewer, documents. He asked if the Committee wanted to have any contact with this group, but they declined.
Kimball suggested that HO should send a shortened form of the list of Foreign Relations volumes available at GPO to the SHAFR newsletter.

Slany raised the matter of public access to the Committee’s records. He asked if the Committee wanted to discuss what documents constituted its records. HO has a list of the documents presently available in the State Department Reading Room, and he asked if the Committee thought additional material should be included. Should correspondence between HO and the Committee be part of the public record? Kimball thought the correspondence was not that voluminous and should be regarded as part of the public record.

Slany noted that HO did not have the correspondence exchanged between members of the Committee. Jane Picker referred to E-Mail. Kimball replied that the substance of the Committee’s E-Mail ended up in its discussions.

Nelson noted that the question of public access to the Committee’s records was discussed in its charter and that the muddy area was that of the closed meetings because of confusion between classified and closed. She thought a procedure for these records should be established according to the Committee’s mandate.
Kimball said that people needed to feel free to discuss private or classified material at these meetings. Nelson pointed out that participants were able to see the minutes before they were approved.

George Chalou commented that the Committee needed to differentiate between reading room material and permanent Committee records. Nelson emphasized that the Committee should be as open as possible. David Langbart noted that the schedule for disposition of the Committee’s records provided for preservation of correspondence and related materials as well as the records of the meetings.

Kimball said that the principle was to open the records. Participants in the closed meetings should specify if they were discussing classified material or material that required protection for other reasons.

Slany noted that there was concern in the Department of State about protection of the deliberative process. People in the Department had objected to sharing internal documents with the Committee and did not want everything they said to be part of the public record. Kimball said he would remind people that they should tell the Committee if they wanted something to be off the record. He noted that the Committee could always say no. The records should be open unless the Committee had agreed that they were not open.

Nelson wondered if this would affect whether people would share information with the Committee. Slany pointed out that awareness of the Committee had increased. In response to a question from Picker, Kimball replied that the fullness of the minutes was not the problem. The Committee had been part of the deliberative process with the Executive order and the State Department was not happy with internal dissent being made public. Ann Van Camp stated that the Department did not want in the public domain a version of the Executive order that was not final.

div.head: Report on Access to Records at the Johnson Library
div.p:
David Humphrey presented a report on access to records at the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library. He said there were two issues. The first was the two State Department-funded positions at the Library that were now vacant. Filling these was
crucial to keeping things moving, and he noted that the Library was working on filling them. Nelson asked if clearances were a problem. Humphrey said no. The positions were funded on a year-by-year basis and many people did not want to go to Texas for a temporary position. Nancy Smith noted that applicants need to have clearances and experience and be willing to move without a moving allowance. Nevertheless, several people were interested.

Humphrey said that the second issue was access to the tapes of the Johnson telephone conversations. HO hopes to soon have tapes for conversations in December 1966 and has requested tapes for 75 conversations in 1967. By the next meeting, we should have a better idea of how fast the Library can process the tapes and how much we will be able to integrate into the volumes.

Nelson asked if all the documentary records were available to HO. Humphrey replied yes; the problem was with the taped conversations. The Library is still in the process of duplicating these onto digital-audio tapes. Nancy Smith pointed out that the existing transcripts are not always accurate and have to be checked against the tapes before publication. Some of the transcripts are highly inaccurate. Humphrey also emphasized that the Library did not want HO to publish transcripts without comparing them with the tapes.

George Herring asked if the question of priorities had been resolved, and Humphrey replied that it had. He noted that HO was submitting requests for tapes for an entire month, such as December 1966. Herring asked if the process was going well. Humphrey replied that it was too early to tell, but the Library was being cooperative.

Kimball asked if that meant there would be no problem meeting the 30-year line. Humphrey said there was a potential problem but it was hard to be precise at this stage; we should have a better idea of the situation by the next meeting.

Kimball asked if there had been a response to the letter to Acting Archivist Trudy Peterson about moving NARA staff to short-term positions. Nancy Smith said not yet. The problem was the need to assure staff members who move to Austin of a permanent job after the project at Austin is completed.

div.head: Move of Department of State Files to Berryville, Virginia
div.p: The Committee then turned to discussion of the projected move of the Department of State Central Foreign Policy File. Ken Lpff, Managing Director of Information Services (A/IM/IS), Edward Wilson, Director of the Office of Information Services (A/IM/IS/OIS), and Willie Gee, Acting Chief of the Records Management Branch (IS/OIS/RA/RD) briefed the Committee.

Loff explained that the site was at Mount Weather, where there is a large FEMA installation that is being converted for various purposes. He noted that the lease at PG Plaza was currently on a month-by-month basis, DS is concerned about security problems there, the facility is leaking, and it is costing the Department $500,000 a year. Loff said the Department had looked at a number of places, and had taken NARA people to look at the Berryville facility. The facility would have to be renovated, but the overall cost would be lower and there would be more space. Loff noted that the trip to the facility at PG Plaza was difficult because of traffic, and he argued that the trip to Mount Weather
would be only “minutes” longer and that FEMA keeps the road clean in winter. He also stated that IS would have a vehicle going back and forth with records as needed.

Van Camp asked if there would be space and a copier available for researchers. Loff confirmed this. Wilson noted there would be a research area with a copier, and researchers would have the same facilities as they had at PG. Ted Keefer noted that this decision had been made without any consultation with HO, a major user of the records. Historians will be faced with driving 67 miles each way. Loff noted that the Records Service Center would make two trips a day to pick up and deliver records between Mt. Weather and Main State. During the meeting, Loff indicated that there would be a shuttle service between Mt Weather and the State Department, but noted later that it was not yet decided if the Department would provide that service. Luke Smith and Keefer commented that historians could work on the records here if there were a working space in the Department. Loff said he was working on this.

Glenn LaFantasie said that a trip to Berryville is much longer than one to PG and noted that the amount of research the HO staff did could not be done in an 8-hour day. Kimball pointed out that IS was ready to move the records, but had not yet found research space here. He commented that IS should have found the research space here first and then planned to move the records. Then personnel-effectiveness, which was separate from cost-effectiveness, would be guaranteed.

Loff said IS wanted people to be happy. He noted that the FEMA facility had apartment space and inexpensive food, in case HO staff needed to stay overnight there. Kimball repeated that IS needed to find research space in the metro area first, before moving the records. He urged that IS establish a working liaison with the HO staff.

Nelson brought up the need for space in the Department for the declassification center, which the Committee had previously supported. Kimball said that the Committee did not want the declassification process delayed. Nelson also noted that the Department needed access to records to deal with FOIA. Loff repeated that there would be a daily shuttle to bring documents back.

Leffler asked whether IS would have the problem of finding research space within the Department solved by the time of the February meeting. Loff replied that he hoped so. Herring asked if the records could be moved without disrupting HO’s research, and Loff said the disruption would be minimal.

Kimball again stated that there needed to be close liaison with HO concerning this. Loff replied that this would happen and apologized for not consulting HO before. Kimball said the Committee would want to make a statement on this.

div.head: Department Response to the Japan Appeal
div.p:
In response to the presence of journalists at the session, Kimball raised the subject of the Department’s response to the appeal regarding the declassification of documents on Japan for the 1961-1963 volume on Northeast Asia. Since substance could not be discussed in a public meeting, he would describe procedure. If the Historian and appropriate officials within the Department of State could not agree on declassification,
they must follow procedures (described in the Foreign Relations law) for a dialogue. If that dialogue reaches an impasse, the law calls for an appeal to the Secretary of State, who had delegated the final authority to Under Secretary for Management Richard Moose. The appeal is on his desk. Technically, the Department is in violation of the law, because nothing has been heard from Moose within the statutory time frame. The Committee will discuss its next step at a closed meeting.

Even if Under Secretary Moose agrees to release the documents for publication, they must go to other agencies that have equity in them. Once these agencies have finished their review and agree, NSC has to do its own review. The entire process could take up to a year. If the documents are declassified, they could be made available to the public at NARA. Herschler qualified this, noting that this would be true if they were documents from the Department of State Central Files. Slany noted that the law provides for a 60-day clock on appeals.

Tim Weiner asked if the 1961-1963 volume on Japan would be published if the verdict on declassification were negative. Kimball stated that the Committee had taken the position that it would recommend against publication of the Japan compilation without the documents. Weiner asked if the Committee could appeal if another agency denied declassification. Kimball replied that the Committee could go to the head of the other agency. Weiner asked if the NSC constituted an appeals court. Kimball said no. Nelson added that subjects other than Japan were included in the volume, and that the preface would presumably indicate why the entire chapter was deleted. Picker pointed out that the deletion would also be noted in the annual report to Congress.

Kimball stressed that the Committee merely advised the Secretary and could not overrule him. It was an advisory body and did not declassify. Both he and Slany said that no date had been set for State’s decision. Nelson asked whether this was the first time that the Committee had recommended not publishing a volume because it was incomplete. Kimball said that it was. Picker stated that the Committee was guided by the statutory language as to whether the omission of the documents would leave an erroneous impression.

Weiner said that the public records of the Committee indicate that a problem was brewing regarding a “country in this hemisphere.” Given the rich public record that exists about this country, did the Committee feel that the withholding of material would be for reasons of embarrassment.

Kimball replied that the country was Guyana, and that the statement in the Committee’s public report should speak for itself. The process and the precedents established in the Japan appeal would help move the process along. He remarked on the need for a balancing test between national security and the public interest, as stated in the draft Executive Order. That was clearly the intent of the legislation on Foreign Relations, as shown in the records of discussions leading up to its adoption. The Committee felt that ethically, philosophically, and legally it should apply this balancing test. Slany pointed out that the Department was still operating under the existing Executive Order, which was different.

Taylor asked Weiner about his sources for his recent New York Times article about CIA involvement in Japanese elections. Weiner stated that they included U. Alexis
Johnson, Douglas MacArthur II, Roger Hilsman, and former director of CIA Far Eastern Operations Al Ulmer. For the rest, he pleaded “sources and methods.”

div.head: Report of the Subcommittee on the Opening of the Department of State’s 30-Year Old Records at the National Archives
div.p: The Committee then turned to a discussion of the declassification review; transfer to the National Archives, and opening to the public of the State Department’s 30-year old records. The subcommittee had visited Archives II at College Park the day before. They examined declassification guidelines and talked to persons involved. Herring expressed his concern that the guidelines seemed over-restrictive and seemed to reflect the climate of an earlier era. Picker felt that it should be possible to issue the guidelines in declassified form. Van Camp noted that agency guidelines had been created at different times, so no overall guidelines existed. Could an inter-agency approach be devised?

Nelson asked whether the Committee had a mandate. Kimball replied that the Committee cared greatly about opening Department of State records. Most guidelines could be declassified. Leffler suggested the Committee go on record as favoring this. Kimball then introduced Tony Dalsimer, the new head of HDR.

Davis agreed with Herring and Picker: certainly the historical summaries included in guidelines should be releasable, and an interagency approach was desirable. Kimball said that either an Executive Order or legislation was desirable. Davis said that the question was how to move forward in the meantime.

Van Camp noted that HDR reviewers worked at NARA. Material segregated was from other agencies. She wondered if HDR could apply the guidelines of other agencies, since archivists had such authority. Kimball said that DOD had a good set of guidelines, which NARA used. DOD had been asked to extend its authority to State documents in its possession. No reply had been received. Kimball continued by saying that the CIA “doesn’t even trust itself.” It has no single declassification authority. NSC also lacked guidelines.

After Leffler asked whether the Committee would go on record as favoring the declassification of guidelines, Kimball said that various “nitpicking things” made the work of HDR reviewers difficult, such as the CIA having cognizance over all biographical materials. In a better world, there would be a single statement, Executive Order, or law.

Page Miller then described how State had complied (or not complied) with legislation. She favored oversight hearings. The 2-year grace period had expired last October, after which Senator Pell read a statement into the record expressing his disappointment. The law did not include penalties for non-compliance. She disagreed with Van Camp that State had done its best and that the problem was with other agencies.

Kimball agreed that State had been slow to take action, but after the first year had devoted additional resources and made significant progress in transferring its records to the National Archives. Now most of the trouble was with other agencies.

Leffler said it was difficult to judge the effectiveness of State’s compliance. He had seen guidelines for one country and was appalled at their extensiveness. Could higher authorities in State be appealed to? Possible goals were declassifying the
guidelines, inter-agency cooperation, and a report on compliance. Once these were addressed, Congress would have something on which to hold hearings.
Herring said that coordination could still be a means of delay. Picker wondered what might happen if other agencies found State’s new guidelines too lax.
The Committee adjourned at 11:20 a.m. to go to a luncheon meeting at the Central Intelligence Agency.

div.head: Closed Session
div.p: Kimball called the meeting to order at 2:55 p.m. after the Committee’s return from the working lunch at the CIA. He asked all those not authorized to attend the closed portion of the meeting to leave.

div.head: Discussion of Committee Minutes
div.p: Kimball then asked members of the Committee to review the minutes of the May meeting and to approve two changes that involved omitting two short phrases that contained classified information. Kimball commented that the changes were necessary so that the minutes could be made public.

Nelson had some reservations about the changes and asked if the minutes would reflect the fact that some information had been omitted. Slany responded that classified information should not have been included in the minutes in the first place.

Nelson was concerned that, if the changes were made, it might appear that the Committee was hiding something. In order to avoid the appearance of concealment, she again suggested that some notation about the omission appear on the minutes. Kimball said he had no objection to including a notation to the effect that the minutes had been edited to remove classified information.

Luke Smith asked whether notetakers should edit the minutes as the notes are recorded. Both Slany and Kimball said no. Kimball went on to say that Slany should do any necessary editing. He also said that the minutes could note that a classified discussion on a particular topic took place without mentioning the specific information discussed.

div.head: Schedule for Future Committee Meetings
div.p: Kimball then moved on to discuss scheduling for upcoming meetings and asked members of the Committee for information concerning their availability. He pointed out that the Committee needed to meet three times prior to August 31, 1995. With that in mind, he reported that a meeting would be scheduled in late January or early February, in May or June, and in August. He conceded that although an August meeting caused problems for many members, they would have to adjust their schedules since August was an ideal time for a meeting. A new chair would be elected about that time, a matter that should be taken care of before the three new members joined the Committee. He also pointed out that August was a good time to meet because it was at the end of the academic year and the time the annual report was prepared.

Nelson asked if copies of Committee minutes and reports would be sent to new members. Kimball replied that they are already receiving material, and he would be sending them information to keep them up-to-speed on the issues facing the Committee.

div.head: Report by Michael Kurtz, Acting Assistant Archivist, on Declassification of Department of State Records
div.p: Kimball moved on to the action items on the agenda, including the meeting of the Committee with the CIA. Before discussing that topic, however, he asked Michael Kurtz Acting Assistant Archivist, to report on the transfer of Department of State records to Archives II.

Kurtz gave a brief review of the progress made to date: The review work has been completed on Department of State Central File documents covering the period from 1960 to 1963; the transfer of 1964-1966 documents to College Park is about to begin; the transfer to Archives II of the civilian classified records was proceeding well and the civilian classified staff would be moving out to College Park in mid-November; military classified documents will be handled in the same manner.

Kimball asked Kurtz about arrangements for liaison and planning for the move so that the down-time for access to documents does not affect the work of HO. Kurtz indicated that an appropriate procedure was in place.

Kurtz then discussed the remaining still classified pre-1945 records and said that all clearances had been received from all U.S. agencies and from the British. Nelson asked whether the documents originated from the period of World War II.

Kurtz explained that the documents were military and civilian records from World War II and that he chose the documents to be part of this declassification project. He also reported that there has been no further information on a pending Executive Order because interagency issues remained unresolved.

That comment spurred Kimball to mention the Committee’s deep concern about the apparent lack of interagency communication. It appeared that Advisory Committee meetings served as the channel for information to be shared. He also told Kurtz that the Committee may be able to help move the declassification process along. Kurtz said he was encouraged by the help the Committee has already provided.

Going back to the topic of inadequate sharing of information among agencies, Kimball gave an example. He said the Committee believed that only recently were declassification guidelines gathered and sent to the Presidential libraries. No one knows why that happened, but it did, and it was unsettling that it happened. He said the problem needs to be solved.
Kurtz concluded his report, and Nelson asked him if he had heard anything from the NSA. Kurtz reported that he had not.

Kimball reported that in September the Deputy Director of NSA sent a rather ambivalent letter to the Committee on the pre-1945 intelligence documents, the Yardley collection, the Magic documents, and the so-called Crane collection. Kimball distributed copies of the letter to the Committee members and attendees from the National Archives. He said he would follow up on the letter, and said he knows that the Department of State has no objections to releasing the material.

div.head: Further Discussion of the Japan Appeal
div.p: Kimball turned to a discussion of the Japan appeal and said that he wanted the Committee’s agreement on how to proceed.

Nelson asked if the discussion of the issue would mean that the minutes of the meeting would be classified. Kimball said they would not discuss substance, but a course of action, so the minutes would not be classified.

Kimball reminded the Committee members that no decision had been received from Moose, and the deadline for his response had already passed. Davis asked if Moose would make a decision today. Van Camp stated that the Committee cannot wait and should do what the law provides—notify Congress. Nelson agreed, because the reply was taking so long.

Kimball pointed out that that was a confrontational action. He suggested as an alternative that he or the Committee write a draft letter, with support from Donilon, informing the Secretary of State that unless the process moved forward, the Committee was prepared to act. Kimball hoped that this would move the process along.

Nelson asked what the Committee would do if the higher authorities said no. Kimball replied that the answer to that question was already in the minutes and the Committee is already on record as to what it would do if declassification was refused. He suggested getting some influence or momentum within the Department in order to get some action. He asked if all members agreed to preparing a draft letter.

Taylor suggested sending a letter directly to Congress. Kimball responded that if the Committee takes a hard line from the start, what happens to the process? It appears that there are conflicting arguments within the Department and maybe beyond the Department, so the lines seem to be drawn already. The best procedure may be for the Committee to remind people that the issue is still open and needs an answer.

Leffler asked if that meant that a letter would not be sent to Congress yet. Kimball replied that at this point only a draft would be written, a friendly letter making it clear that the Committee insists that action be taken on this matter.

After further discussion, everyone on the Committee except Taylor agreed to the nonconfrontational approach at this time. Taylor had some reservations. He suggested including in the draft letter a concrete timeframe for a reply. Kimball agreed and suggested the letter ask for a response within 2 weeks. Picker suggested a deadline before Thanksgiving or before the holidays.

Van Camp asked if it might be possible to get an answer on the issue today. Slany said that Under Secretary Moose wants to make a positive decision, but the fact that he has not given a decision indicates that he is trying to respond to conflicting advice from different bureaus in the Department. He is taking the matter seriously.

Kimball added that Deputy Assistant Secretary Bennett Freeman spoke to Under Secretary Moose about the matter. If any information is received from Freeman, Kimball would hold off submitting the draft letter. No decision was expected, however. Kimball expressed the Committee’s sentiment that it was time to take some action. The Committee had been patient, but the 60-day clock began in June and expired in August,
so a decision had to be made. Moose had pretty much said that a decision would be made in October.

Slany said that HO itself has not acted quickly either. It is difficult for us to educate others who have different approaches and points of view on such matters. At least the issue is being given serious consideration, and that is a major change for the better.

Returning to the course the Committee should follow, Kimball emphasized that the Committee does not want confrontation, but cooperation. Taylor asked if sending a letter to Congress was confrontational. Herring suggested that the Committee must indicate that it had gone beyond thinking about acting, that it was prepared to act.

Kimball asked if it was time to compromise. Taylor responded that a compromise was not needed. If the rest of the Committee did not agree to send the letter to Congress, he would go along with it, but he wished his reservation to be noted in the minutes.

Kimball replied that he would enclose a draft letter containing the Committee’s position in an unofficial and personal note to Donilon. The note will say that the letter will be sent to the Secretary and to Congress, if nothing is done on the matter now. Van Camp suggested that the letter be sent only to Donilon and not be shared with others. Kimball agreed saying that he had received an unofficial letter from Donilon and he would write back unofficially.

Kimball said that the Committee agrees (except for Taylor) that he should draft a letter to Donilon concerning the Japan appeal, saying that the Committee is preparing a note for the Secretary of State (which would also go to Congress) if M does not decide about the Japan appeal soon. The letter would not be confrontational, but would point out that the 60-day legislated timeframe for responding to the appeal has expired.

Van Camp stressed that the letter should go only to Donilon at this point. Kimball agreed that it is his intention that the letter go to Donilon only, but added that it is no secret that the Committee feels strongly about this.

div.head: Further Discussion of the Move of Department of State Files to Berryville
div.p: Kimball asked for someone to draft a letter containing a Committee response to the proposed move of State Department records to Berryville. He said that the two main issues the Committee is concerned about are: 1) the creation of an adequate working space in or close to the Department; and 2) there should be liaison with HO in the move plans so that the transfer of documents does not conflict with the HO schedule. Humphrey added (and the Committee agreed) that the workspace and equipment must be adequate at the Berryville site.
Leffler suggested that Slany draft the letter and the Committee sign it. The Committee agreed.

div.head: Further Discussion of Declassification Guidelines
div.p:
Kimball said that the Committee would like to be involved in making declassification guidelines less restrictive, and he and Herring asked rhetorically “What
are we trying to protect?” Slany asked if the Committee was willing to come back to review the guidelines. The Committee nodded.

Van Camp explained that most of the guidelines were originally written for NARA’s use, but the situation has changed and State has assumed most of the responsibility. She suggested that this is an opportunity to reshape how guidelines are prepared for use with the 1964-1966 record block.
Marvin Russell said that NARA still needs guidelines. He gave an example of State records in USIA files.

Van Camp reiterated that this is a good window of opportunity to reshape the State guidelines. Nelson noted that the guidelines are also important because they are used by archivists for mandatory review, etc.

Kimball asked Dalsimer what is the status of the 1964-1966 guidelines. Dalsimer responded that HDR is working on them. Hamilton explained that Morefield is working on new guidelines and has prepared a concept paper on the scope of the 1964-1966 guidelines. He noted that the guidelines are taking into account the change to the subject-numeric filing system. He explained that HDR had drafted the guidelines for the administrative part of the file first for two reasons: 1) they go faster and 2) they come first in the subject-numeric system. He added that they respond to the priorities they are given.

Kimball asked Dalsimer if there are ways to create a consultative process between HO and HDR. He said that the Committee “does not declassify, we are concerned about concepts,” as in “What is the philosophy behind declassification?” Dalsimer and Hamilton consulted and Hamilton said this was possible.

Nancy Smith commented that State can issue guidelines for unclassified documents that are less than 30 years old (as the NSC did). She was continuing when Kimball interjected that specifics are unnecessary at this time; she could work out the issue with Dalsimer.
Kurtz said that NARA will send requests to State.

Nelson again raised the earlier question of what now must remain secret, and said that there is a lack of clarity. Herring commented that it is more than a lack of clarity, it is an issue of consistency. Nelson continued that the Committee feels that there are contradictions in the guidelines.

Kimball said that one thing we should do is have one compiler work with HDR to try to play a role to help HDR create the guidelines that they are doing now. Dalsimer agreed that that sounded plausible, and Slany also agreed. Kimball said that Slany and Dalsimer will talk about this, and then the Committee will discuss it through E-Mail. (There was a lively discussion about E-Mail and the refusal of some Committee members to use it.) He added that the Committee wants to take action, but needs to know what to do.

Leffler asked about the declassification of the old guidelines. Pryor reminded the Committee that the new guidelines refer to the old ones. Herring commented that they should start with a clean slate.

Leffler reiterated that the Committee is looking for an opportunity to advise on the guidelines. Reviewing them in draft form would be a good opportunity to comment on them before they are final. Dalsimer noted that it would not be necessary to put the
request in writing but that he would like it put in the minutes. Kimball repeated for the notetakers that they are talking about looking at existing guidelines to declassify as much as possible.

Kimball noted that the lack of interagency coordination of declassification procedures would be alleviated if the new Executive order was promulgated. Leffler questioned that and said that a consequence of that could be to make it more restrictive. Davis asked what made Leffler so pessimistic, and Nelson interjected “experience.” Davis said that between JCS (and DOD, etc.) and State, JCS is more liberal.

Kimball brought up the British system of automatic declassification and asked which is better. Nelson pointed out that a system that is too orderly could be a problem. Kimball said that what Leffler is saying is that we could benefit from the confusion that arose from a lack of interagency coordination.

Van Camp said that we shouldn’t second guess the new Executive order, that it is late in the day to question the executive order since the Committee has gone on record as supporting it. She said that we must reiterate our support of this.

Picker suggested that they ask someone in the State hierarchy about what should remain secret. Kimball said that all of the desk officers will say: “Everything on my country should remain classified, and release everything else.”

Slany advised that the Committee should await the outcome of the new Executive order before seeking an explanation from Under Secretary Moose or another Department official about the principles of the Department of State for retaining classification on documents.

Picker asked if it is possible to know if any papers or studies have been written on the basis of documents declassified under the 1960-1963 guidelines for countries such as the Soviet Union, where so much more has been declassified.

Herring said that what is in effect are the older guidelines from 1955 to 1959. He added that these were drafted in the 1980s. Hamilton said that the new guidelines state what is still sensitive and they were prepared in 1992-1993. Picker reiterated that in drafting the guidelines HDR needs more direction from on high rather than simply relying on their own individual judgment.

Pryor said that the 1960-1963 guidelines were completed in 1993 on the basis of HDR’s review of the old guidelines. The 1960-1963 guidelines identify what is still sensitive and what is not. She said that in drafting the guidelines they used their own judgment as well as Bureau advice. Kimball said that he believed that the philosophical approach had been covered within the Department under the discussion of the new Executive order. Picker pointed out that it is hard to link the Executive order and the guidelines from the legal standpoint.

Kimball said that the guidelines will have to be rewritten. The Committee should wait to evaluate the consultative process, keeping in mind the question of “what are we trying to protect.” A subcommittee will deal with the issue at the next meeting.

div.head: Report of the Subcommittee on Records
div.p:
Van Camp reported on her subcommittee’s examination of the Africa Bureau files with respect to a new disposition schedule covering the files created since 1990. At the
last meeting they were asked to look at the records schedule for the Bureau of African Affairs. Yesterday the subcommittee visited the Bureau to look at the schedules and visit the offices to see what kind of records are in their files. The recommendation of the subcommittee is that this schedule is adequate for these records. Some of the files will be permanently retained, while others are designated to be destroyed (some in the short term and some in the long). She said that the subcommittee thinks that the schedule is appropriate and recommended that it go forward.

She also recommended that HO work with the records management staff to develop guidelines and procedures for screening files by other offices before destruction to ensure that all appropriate historical records are preserved in the Central Files. She added that the subcommittee had discussed this with the Records Management staff and they believed that this was workable.
Kimball asked if the Committee agreed, and they concurred in the recommendations.

Van Camp brought up the issue of the disposition of records scheduled for destruction and whether an outside institution can request custody of those records. The current procedure is that once the schedule is approved, the institution can ask State to seek NARA’s permission to take custody of the disposable files.

Taylor said that the Committee could say that the issue of disposition should be left open to include other arrangements. He said that the Committee should clearly endorse the principle that such records might go to an interested institution. (Taylor’s comments in the form of a letter to Van Camri are in Annex 1.)

Nelson said the Committee should “encourage” if not endorse the principle. Leffler added that it should not incur government expense. Taylor agreed and said that it should be at the expense of the institution.
Kimball asked if the Committee was in agreement.

Van Camp said that the Committee’s responsibility is to advise the State Department on its records, but what happens to duplicate files (at the time of their ultimate disposition) is not the Committee’s business.

Kimball said that the Committee might say that, in the spirit of public access to foreign policy records, the Advisory Committee encourages practices and measures that will lead to the availability of duplicate sets of records in outside depositories and will look with favor on any action to preserve these records.

Van Camp said that she is not sure what the outcome of this would be. If the records disposition process works, this kind of thing should not be necessary. She said that the disposition process should take its course.

Kimball added that it makes people more sensitive to the records. He called it to a vote. The Committee voted that the Advisory Committee is in favor of “nose-sticking.” He requested that Van Camp draft an appropriate statement (see Annex 2).

Van Camp said that in talking to the desk officers the subcommittee got the sense that the deliberative process within the offices is not adequately reflected in the records because of E-Mail and other issues. She suggested that the subcommittee should examine this issue.
Kimball said that it would be useful if her subcommittee consult Ken Rossman and the Records Management staff and put together a list of items for the subcommittee to focus on at the next meeting.

div.head: Foreign Relations Coordinator in HDR
div.p: Kimball said that the Committee has learned that Jeanne Pryor is leaving HDR on November 1. He remarked that she had made an important contribution to the series and applauded her good management. He added that many problems had been solved during her tenure in HDR and thanked her for her contribution. There was general applause. He hoped that her replacement would continue the good work. Dalsimer introduced Nina Noring as Pryor’s replacement. Kimball commented that because Noring is a former member of the Historical Office, the Committee anticipated a high level of cooperation with HO.

div.head: Report on the Visit to the Central Intelligence Agency
div.p: Kimball said that the last item on the agenda is to summarize the CIA visit. He suggested that they write a memorandum to Hazlewood summarizing the positive things that Hazlewood said in their meeting. For example, all covert operations reflect foreign policy goals, therefore it is in our purview. He asked the members to E-Mail him on this.
Herring commented that they also seemed to be forthcoming on the issue of provenance.

Leffler said that the Agency was willing to acknowledge to HO where covert operations occurred, so the Foreign Relations volumes can document them. The Committee disagreed on what the CIA meant by this acknowledgment. Nelson said that this is acknowledgment for research and access purposes, not for declassification.

Kimball recalled his complaint about the problem of plausible deniability, that the historians must ask the right question to get the right answer. CIA had asked for examples of this. Kimball explained that LaFantasie had raised the issue of Tibet documents, very few of which had been found at the CIA. Kimball said that it is “memoranda blizzard time.” The historians have to explain and request every little thing, and then send memoranda to McDonald explaining that they have been told that there are no documents on a particular subject.

Leffler said that McDonald claimed that no HO historian had ever left his office dissatisfied; he asked for an example. Schwar said that she sent a letter to CIA specifically asking for documents on Tibet. She did not write a response to CIA’s reply. Luke Smith said that the history staff at CIA does not always know if there are documents on a subject. Kimball repeated the need for a paper trail and asked Slany to work out a process, and the Advisory Committee will see if it agrees to it.

Leffler said that the CIA said that they will respond affirmatively if we ask if covert operations—not actions—occurred in certain countries. Kimball emphasized that the historians must be specific when wording their requests. Nelson also recalled that they were told that “finding aid” means something different to the CIA than it does to the
Department of State, so the historians should use the term “shelf list” instead. Kimball repeated that he will write a memorandum on these issues but needs help from the Committee.
Kimball cleared the room except for HO staff at 4:25 p.m.

div.head: HO Staff Comments
div.p: Slany remarked that the Committee had asked about publication of our volumes on CD/ROM. Vicki Futscher is working on this for the Office. Later, a single CD will include the text of all 25 Kennedy volumes. He distributed copies of the Department’s first CD/ROM publication containing public statements and publications such as Dispatch to the Committee.

Nelson noted that many colleges don’t have the equipment to access these types of publications, and she hoped that this would not replace print volumes. Slany assured the Committee that publication on CD/ROM would not replace the printed Foreign Relations volumes; it would provide an additional means for the dissemination of the volumes.

Kimball stated that the Committee will take a strong position on the move of the Department of State records to Berryville. He assumes that it will take place, but the Committee will try to help to make it workable. Patterson said that the declassification center in the Department of State (when established) might be able to house the Central Files, which are stored in cabinets. What takes space is the lot files (office and post files), which can be pulled in quickly when needed, but the Central Files are different. Kimball reiterated that HO needs to be consulted on the move. He will send a memorandum to Ken Loff on the declassification center and to Assistant Secretary Donilon saying that the Committee is eager for it to be established.

Luke Smith commented that if a compiler is asked to participate in the work on the guidelines it will take away from the time he or she has to compile manuscripts. Kimball responded that Foreign Relations will still take priority but that HO participation is necessary.

He noted that he had again raised the issue with HDR for formal training for HDR declassifiers. He added that the Committee has raised it before, but nothing was done. Hamilton had told them that informal training was done, but the Committee agreed that that was not sufficient. Finally, he noted that Dalsimer had said he could arrange for the Committee to go to the NSC.
The meeting adjourned at 4:35 p.m.
College of Arts & Sciences department of historyOctober 6, 1994
Dr. Anne Van Camp
Hoover Institution Archives
Hoover Institution
Stanford, California
Dear Anne,
My views on the subjects in your attached memo of 9/29/94 are as follows:

1. Records of historical value scheduled for destruction when ten years old should be reviewed after five or seven years to determine if they may be released before the scheduled disposal date. Meanwhile a subcommittee of the Advisory Committee might review some of the records scheduled for destruction when ten years old or earlier to assess their historical value and make recommendations regarding their disposal, provided, of course, the State Department allows the committee access to those records. With these understandings we should endorse the proposed schedule for disposition of the records.

2. Records of historical value that are scheduled for destruction should be donated to organizations that can make efficient use of them for teaching and/or research purposes. Howard University is an ideal depository for the African Bureau records because of its historical and current interest and involvement in African affairs, the number of Africa area specialists on its faculty, its African Studies Department and Program, and its recently established International Studies Research Center.

3. Since HO has requested our advice, the committee should proffer its opinion and suggestions. Moreover, the spirit of our general mandate, if not the letter, should validate our interest in enhancing public access to the unclassified records of the State Department.
I hope some of these views fall within the parameters of the assignment that we were given.
Sincerely,
cc: W. Kimball, M. Leffler

p.hi: Statement on Disposal of Department of State Records

div.p: If and when the Department of State is at the point of disposing of records no longer needed, and if and when outside entities should then offer to receive such records at no cost to the government and in keeping with all relevant regulations, this Committee would look with favor on Departmental responsiveness in such cases.
